title: Fitch Assigns Shangrao Investment Group First-Time 'BBB-'; Outlook Stable
text:
Fitch Assigns Shangrao Investment Group First-Time 'BBB-'; Outlook Stable

(The following statement was released by the rating agency) Fitch Ratings-Hong Kong-October 11: Fitch Ratings has assigned China-based Shangrao Investment Holding Group Co., Ltd.'s (SIHG) first-time Long-Term Foreign- and Local-Currency Issuer Default Ratings of 'BBB-' with a Stable Outlook. SIHG is a primary investment and financing entity for the Shangrao municipal government to invest and operate in various key business segments and assets, including urban development and infrastructure construction, water supply and sewage, toll roads, public transportation and airport operation, tourism and financial services. Key Rating Drivers Very Strong Status, Ownership and Control: SIHG is 97.6% owned by the Shangrao State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (Shangrao SASAC). The company is directly managed, supervised and controlled by Shangrao government via Shangrao SASAC. The board of directors is SIHG's highest decision-making body. All board members are either appointed or nominated by the municipal committee and the government. Any changes in the board of supervisors or the board of directors need to be approved by the government. 'Strong' Support Record and Expectations: SIHG has a record of receiving frequent support from the Shangrao government, including subsidies and capital injections. Government subsidies accounted for 50% of net profit from 2016-2018. The subsidies were mainly to support urban development projects. In addition, the Shangrao SASAC has increased the company's paid-in capital of CNY8.7 billion by cash during 2017 and 2018. The government has swapped a total of CNY13.0 billion of the company's debt since 2014. 'Strong' Socio-Political Implications of Default: We believe a default by SIHG could adversely affect the municipality's urban development, key public utilities and tourism, in light of the strategic importance of the assets it operates as well as its almost monopolistic status in these areas. A default by SIHG would hurt the municipality, as its wide-ranging businesses affect the municipality's everyday operations and it cannot be immediately substituted by other entities. 'Very Strong' Financial Implications of Default: We believe a default by SIHG would hamper significantly the municipality's financing capacity. The government exploits its primary financing and investment entity to facilitate urban development projects and operate critical public utilities. Public works under the contractual framework are awarded to public entities, which rely on SIHG for the majority of financing to make these essential public works viable. 'b' Standalone Credit Profile: Fitch assesses SIHG's Standalone Credit Profile as 'b', based on a 'Midrange' demand defensibility, 'Midrange' operating risk and 'Weaker' financial profile. SIHG's financial profile in the past few years has been characterised by large capex and high leverage, resulting in a Fitch-adjusted net debt/EBITDA ratio of 30x in 2018. RATING SENSITIVITIES A change in Fitch's credit assessment of the Shangrao municipality or the municipality's ability to provide subsidies, grants or other legitimate resources allowed under China's policies and regulations could result in a change in SIHG's ratings. A significant weakening of the socio-political and financial implications of a default by SIHG or deterioration in Fitch's expectations of support, or a dilution of the government's shareholding, may result in a downgrade. An improvement or deterioration of SIHG's Standalone Credit Profile or liquidity position of SIHG would also affect the ratings.
